prior_works.title: Automatic Goal Generation for Reinforcement Learning Agents (GoalGAN)
prior_works.authors: Adrià Florensa, David Held, Xinyang Geng, Pieter Abbeel
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ACES’ practice of measuring problem difficulty through the solver’s success rate and steering generation toward challenging-but-solvable instances directly echoes GoalGAN’s idea of sampling goals near the agent’s success boundary (~50% success).

prior_works.title: Teacher-Student Curriculum Learning
prior_works.authors: T. Matiisen, A. Oliver, T. Cohen, J. Schulman
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ACES operationalizes a curriculum signal from solver performance, aligning with teacher-student approaches that use learning progress/success feedback to adaptively select task difficulty.

prior_works.title: Illuminating Search Spaces by Mapping Elites (MAP-Elites)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ACES’ joint drive for diversity and performance across a hand-crafted descriptor space of programming skills mirrors MAP-Elites’ core principle of covering a behavior descriptor space while optimizing a quality metric.

prior_works.title: POET: Paired Open-Ended Trailblazer
prior_works.authors: Rui Wang, Joel Lehman, Kenneth O. Stanley, Jeff Clune
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By iteratively generating harder yet solvable problems and coupling them with a solver, ACES adopts POET’s open-ended paradigm of co-evolving diverse, increasingly challenging environments with solution capabilities.

prior_works.title: Unsupervised Learning of Goal Spaces for Intrinsically Motivated Goal Exploration
prior_works.authors: Adrien Laversanne-Finot, Félix Garcia Ortiz (Pere), Pierre-Yves Oudeyer
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ACES’ autotelic framing and explicit goal/problem space construction resonate with IMGEP work on learning goal spaces that support diverse, self-generated exploration and curricula.

prior_works.title: Language as a Cognitive Tool to Imagine Goals in Reinforcement Learning
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ACES’ use of LLM-generated semantic descriptors for programming skills directly builds on the idea that language can define and structure goal spaces for autotelic exploration.

synthesis_narrative:
ACES fuses two influential strands: intrinsic motivation for autotelic task generation and quality-diversity search over interpretable descriptors. From the curriculum-learning side, GoalGAN and Teacher–Student Curriculum Learning showed that a solver’s success rate is a rich signal to target goals on the frontier of competence—challenging but learnable. ACES adopts this principle almost verbatim by defining problem difficulty as an inverse function of a strong LLM solver’s success rate and steering generation toward those hard-yet-solvable regions.

From the diversity side, MAP-Elites established how to simultaneously maximize coverage of a descriptor space while optimizing a quality measure. ACES mirrors this architecture by representing programming problems in an LLM-defined semantic descriptor space (e.g., dynamic programming, string manipulation) and seeking broad coverage while pushing difficulty upward. POET extends this logic to open-ended, co-evolving environments and solvers; ACES echoes POET’s autotelic loop by iteratively generating new problems and evaluating solvability with a capable solver, thus maintaining a moving frontier of challenge.

Finally, autotelic goal exploration work in IMGEP and follow-ups on language-grounded goals supplied the representational and conceptual substrate for ACES’ descriptor design. The choice to let language models produce semantic skill tags and to drive exploration through these tags is a direct continuation of using language to structure goal spaces. Together, these works crystallize in ACES as a QD-style, autotelic loop guided by solver success—now instantiated with LLMs as both designer (problem generator/descriptor annotator) and evaluator (difficulty estimator).
